title: Amid Brexit, a Different Common Currency Is Raising a Ruckus
text:
Your money’s no good here: People in England aren’t required to accept pounds printed by Scottish banks.

LONDON— David Swanson sheepishly shoved the bill back in his wallet. His crime? Trying to pay for two pints in a British pub with Scottish money.

A skeptical bartender instead had nudged him toward a credit-card reader on the bar top.

“I wish I had a pound”—an English one, that is—“for every time I’ve had to explain that they’re okay,” Mr. Swanson said, fishing out a debit card. “Maybe I’ll keep this one for the taxi.”

He’s going to keep trying

Scottish pounds have been printed in some form since before the country’s union with England over 300 years ago. They are legitimate money, each backed by an equivalent value of Bank of England notes under guard at the central bank in London.

But merchants in Britain are free to refuse them. And they do.

“Have you got something else on you?” said David Talbot, when offered a Scottish tenner at his west London fruit stall recently. He said other customers would be annoyed to receive them as change.

Brexit is picking at old wounds. Britain voted to leave the European Union, but nearly two-thirds of people in Scotland voted to stay. Now, a narrow Scottish majority favors breaking away from Britain, according to one recent opinion poll, and others show growing support for the idea after the country rejected the idea in 2014.

A wallpaper pattern made from Scottish banknotes. Photo: iStock

If that were to happen, Scotland’s largest political party has suggested dropping the pound and creating a new currency. Scottish comic Kevin Bridges offered up the name “smackeroonies.”

To defuse some of the tension and help keep Britain together, Scottish lawmaker Alistair Carmichael has proposed a new law to compel people across the U.K. to accept Scottish bank notes, no questions asked.

The bill is unlikely to be passed—or even discussed—any time soon, since British Prime Minister Boris Johnson moved to suspend the U.K. Parliament as Britain prepares to leave the EU.

Mr. Carmichael’s staff said that, like Scottish hero Robert the Bruce, he would try, and try again, once a new session begins.

“It’s not just a question of whether your money’s good or not. It’s also about respect,” he said. “We’ve been grumbling about it for years.”

Scotland and England fought a series of wars from the 10th to 12th centuries that set the border they share roughly where it is today. They were formally united in 1707.

As the British empire began to shrink in the 20th century, Scotland started pushing for a better deal. Referendums in the 1970s and 1990s established some limited autonomy.

Mr. Carmichael, who represents the Orkney and Shetland islands off the country’s craggy northeastern coast, reckons the nationalists could lose some of their momentum if the Scots’ southern neighbors took their currency at face value.

Lawmaker Alistair Carmichael is pushing legislation to make people in England and other parts of Britain accept Scottish banknotes. Photo: JAMES HOOKWAY/THE WALL STREET JOURNAL

Scottish notes are part of the country’s identity. They match the shape and size of English notes, but instead of Queen Elizabeth, they feature Scottish icons like the poet Robert Burns or Robert the Bruce, who, legend has it, was inspired to fight for Scotland’s independence in the 14th century after watching a spider rebuild its broken web over and over.

It’s the same with bank notes printed by Northern Ireland’s commercial banks, although those are less often seen in England. (Wales uses Bank of England notes.)

There are around £4.4 billion-worth of Scottish bills in circulation, compared with £70 billion of English pounds.

But they aren’t “legal tender,” meaning that nobody is required to accept them as payment.

Worse, many people in England—around a third in one recent survey—think they are fake.

Dozens of videos on YouTube and Facebook show people trying to pay for things in England with Scottish bank notes or attempting to swap them with English ones at foreign-exchange booths. Small shopkeepers often refuse them outright.

Share Your Thoughts Have you ever had a Scottish pound rejected? Join the conversation below.

“It does my head in, the number of times people hold up my money and inspect it,” said Katie Caldwell, who often travels to London on business from her home outside Edinburgh.

A currency is only as good as one’s ability to spend it. Squirrel pelts moved easily enough around medieval Russia; less so the 12-foot diameter limestone wheels that served as money on the Micronesian island of Yap, and which are still used today in traditional ceremonies.

Scottish notes were briefly designated as legal tender during World War I, when the British government wanted to encourage the use of paper money to prevent hoarding of gold.

But they lost their status in peacetime, and various legislative efforts in the 20th century to put them on even footing have failed.

Judy Murray and Andy Murray at the practice courts at Wimbledon in July. Photo: I-Images/Zuma Press

Mario Von Poppel, who runs a currency exchange in London, buys Scottish twenties for £18.40, tens for £9.20 and fives for £4.60—this despite the fact that they are equivalent in the eyes of the British treasury.

Scottish lawmaker Stephen Kerr was sufficiently aggrieved when his Royal Bank of Scotland £20 was turned down at a newsstand at London’s City Airport recently that he went to the Scottish newspapers to complain. A Scottish tabloid photographed him holding up the offending note like it was an expired lottery ticket.

Mr. Kerr said he is inclined to support Mr. Carmichael’s bill to expand the use of Scottish notes, though he prefers a public relations blitz over a legal one.

Celebrity is no protection. Tennis coach Judy Murray, mother of Scotland’s former Wimbledon champion Andy Murray, took to Twitter this spring when her £10 Bank of Scotland note was turned down in a London cake shop.

“We only take British ones,” she said the clerk told her.

Write to James Hookway at james.hookway@wsj.com
description: Despite 300 years of union, pounds from Scottish banks—with icons such as Robert the Bruce and Robert Burns—aren’t legal tender in England; ‘It does my head in, the number of times people hold up my money and inspect it.’
